title: Before 1 January 2019, will South Korean President Moon Jae-in visit Pyongyang?
preds:
September 18, 2018 / 1:09 AM / Updated 6 minutes ago
Leaders of two Koreas meet in Pyongyang for talks on ending war
Hyonhee Shin, Joyce Lee 5 Min Read SEOUL (Reuters) - North Korean’s Kim Jong Un greeted Moon Jae-in with hugs and smiles on Tuesday as the South Korean president arrived in Pyongyang to discuss faltering talks on denuclearization and the prospect of officially ending the Korean War. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-southkorea-summit/leaders-of-two-koreas-meet-in-pyongyang-for-talks-on-ending-war-idUSKCN1LX1SC?il=0

I believe there is a 100% chance that Kim Jong Un and Moon Jae-in will meet in Pyongyang. In fact, unless there are major set-backs, the two are meant to meet this week. In preparation for this meeting, a delegation of South Korean officials visited North Korea earlier in September to lay the groundwork for the upcoming meeting. The meeting appeared to go well as Kim Jong Un was pictured smiling and laughing with the envoy. Although the US and North Korea are going through tensions at the moment, because of South Korea's role as the mediator, I believe it would be very unlikely for North Korea to cancel the meeting with South Korea (or vice-versa) because South Korea has been acting more neutral as of recently, and wants to continue building dialogue with North Korea in order to build trust. In this quote, Moon Jae-in discusses his neutrality to the situation, and places South Korea on the outskirts of the conflict between the US and North Korea, "The complete denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula is an issue that should fundamentally be resolved between the US and North Korea through negotiation...But until talks and communication between the North and the US become more active, we cannot but work to mediate between them...President Trump and Chairman Kim have asked that I play this role."  Moreover, the two have already met previously this year, laying a solid foundation to their relationship. Lastly, because Kim Jong Un is eager to have another meeting with Trump, he will most likely want this meeting to occur between himself and Moon Jae-in. https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/world/asia/2018-09-17-south-korean-leader-steps-in-to-break-nuclear-deadlock-at-pyongyang-summit/
https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2162792/south-korean-envoys-head-north-korea-bid-revive-nuclear-talks
https://www.firstpost.com/world/moon-jae-in-calls-for-bold-decision-from-us-and-north-korea-on-denuclearisation-says-leaders-asked-him-to-mediate-negotiations-5159251.html
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/south-korean-envoys-hold-first-talks-in-north-after-us-halted-pompeo-visit/2018/09/05/337d9ed4-b07d-11e8-8b53-50116768e499_story.html?utm_term=.a7ff6503dcd7

They're on for Tuesday, barring a major cataclysm. http://theweek.com/speedreads/796213/south-koreas-moon-jaein-makes-historic-trip-pyongyang-tuesday?utm_campaign=newsletter&utm_source=afternoon&utm_medium=09_16_18-article_3-796213

Going to 100 because they currently have a meeting scheduled for later this month. While normally I assume North Korea is going to break its word, lately they have been on something of a charm offensive so I am staying optimistic until the summit later this week.
Both Korean Kahunas need to put on a show for the US President and their domestic markets.  Doesn't matter what they say or do at the meeting; the point for both is to have a lovely meeting.
They have a meeting scheduled for September, but the unpredictability of North Korea is a large reason for which I am not confident to go over 93%.
The two leaders have a summit scheduled for September.

Update: The Pyongyang visit on 18th to 20th September has been announced by many media outlets. I still can't find confirmation from North Korea, but maybe that's  only because I can't find any English speaking official North Korean media outlets. The Pyongyang Times (www.pyongyangtimes.com.kp) is supposed to be such an outlet but I just get a browser timeout message when trying to access it. So I'm going to stick my neck out a bit and put this at 100%. All four players (China, USA, North Korea, South Korea) have their own motives for making this process work. We now have a press center for the 3rd inter-Korean summit scheduled to take place between September 18-20. Even though the summit will be in Pyongyang, the press center will be set up at Dongdaemun Design Plaza in central Seoul and provide live coverage

Kim showing unusual signs of calm rational behavior. But there is always paths that can occur to cancel the meeting.  At least 4 % more likely 8%. But I'll lean rich at 4%  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/06/north-korea-kim-moon-meeting-trump-nuclear

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/06/north-korea-kim-moon-meeting-trump-nuclear South Korea’s president, Moon Jae-in, will travel to North Korea for a third meeting with the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, as denuclearisation talks with the US stall. 
 Moon would travel to Pyongyang between 18 and 20 September, said Chung Eui-yong, head of the South’s National Security Office, as he returned from a one-day meeting with Kim in North Korea. It will be the third time this year the leaders of the two Koreas have met, after talks in the border village of Panmunjom in April and May.

A high-level South Korean delegation will fly to North Korea this week to discuss arrangements for an inter-Korean summit there this month, as relations grow cooler between Washington and Pyongyang. The South’s President Moon Jae-in Sunday (Sept 2) named his top security adviser as a special envoy to the North to discuss details before Moon’s planned meeting in Pyongyang with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

China's taking more of an interest in influencing both Pyongyang as well as Seoul.  I predict they'll be a meeting between the two leaders BEFORE the first of the new year - - -  most likely around the 3rd week in December.

"Seoul proposed the envoy’s visit Friday morning and Pyongyang accepted it a few hours later". https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2162291/s-koreas-moon-send-special-envoy-pyongyang-next-week

Also, like it or not, the Trump administration appears to be using economic leverage against China to get their support in forcing NK to negotiate and act earnestly towards peaceful developments on the peninsula.

No date was mentioned for the next summit leaving analysts to conclude that both sides could not agree on one. Pyongyang wanted it to take place before Sept 9, the anniversary of North Korea's founding, Dr Park Jee-kwang from Sejong Institute think tank told The Straits Times.  But Seoul, wary of Pyongyang taking advantage of the summit for domestic propaganda, preferred to hold it just before the start of the United Nations General Assembly on Sept 18, he added.
            ...The delegations also discussed "further methods to fulfil the Declaration in a sincere manner", said a joint statement.  South Korea's Unification Minister Cho Myoung-gyon, who led the talks with North Korea's chief delegate Ri Son Gwon, said that Pyongyang was asked to speed up nuclear disarmament talks, to which it replied that it was "pushing forward with steps agreed to with the United States".
            ...Pressure has been mounting on Seoul to play a more active role in mediating between Pyongyang and Washington, after denuclearisation talks hit a stalemate following the Trump-Kim summit in Singapore on June 12.  Dr Park said: "There is pressure from the US to press North Korea to give up nuclear weapons, but the progressive Moon Jae-in government is friendly towards the North and has little intention to pressure them."  He added that while Mr Trump has so far been patient with Mr Kim, "it will be disastrous for North Korea if Trump changes his mind and starts doubting North Korea's intentions."
https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/third-moon-kim-summit-set-for-next-month Afterward, he said a date has been fixed but not announced, “to keep reporters wondering.”   U.S. officials have privately expressed irritation at the breakneck pace of the rapprochement between the North and South amid stalled denuclearization talks with Washington. 
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/north-south-koreans-press-on-with-peace-process-aiming-for-pyongyang-summit/2018/08/13/674ca672-9eb4-11e8-b562-1db4209bd992_story.html?utm_term=.40c9ba6985de https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/13/world/asia/north-south-korea-third-summit.html
Rival Korea leaders to meet in Pyongyang in September: http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/rival-korea-leaders-to-meet-in-pyongyang-in-september/ar-BBLQOuE?ocid=ientp

North and South Korean officials began high-level negotiations on Monday, with one South Korean newspaper report suggesting the two sides could be planning for a summit in Pyongyang later this month.  ...“As the Pyongyang summit of the leaders of North and South Korea is being pursued, I believe that we can give concrete answers to the problems that the people hope and wish for,” Ri said during the talks, according to South Korea’s Unification Ministry. Citing an unidentified South Korean official, the Kookmin Ilbo newspaper reported earlier on Monday that the next summit could be held as soon as late August. The schedule had mostly been coordinated with North Korea and the summit would likely be held in Pyongyang, it said. A spokesman for South Korea’s presidential Blue House said on Sunday officials hoped such details would be decided at Monday’s talks.
https://in.reuters.com/article/northkorea-southkorea-talks/north-south-korea-begin-talks-before-possible-pyongyang-summit-idINKBN1KY06E "Pyongyang will be considered the venue by default under the joint declaration, but I do not believe we must say it can only be held in Pyongyang or that the venue has been set with no possible changes," Cheong Wa Dae spokesman Kim Eui-kyeom told a daily press briefing.
http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2018/08/10/0200000000AEN20180810004500315.html A senior North Korean official suggested Monday that the leaders of North and South Korea may meet in Pyongyang, as envoys from the rival nations discussed setting a summit date and venue amid an ongoing nuclear standoff.  "The discussions about the North and South Korea leaders' meeting in Pyongyang are underway," Ri Son Gwon, chairman of the North Korean agency that deals with inter-Korean affairs, told the South Korean delegation in opening remarks Monday, according to pool reports. Ri compared the Koreas to very close friends with an unbreakable bond.  The meeting at a North Korea-controlled building in the border village of Panmunjom comes amid growing worries about whether North Korea will begin abandoning its nuclear weapons, something officials suggested would happen after Kim's summit with President Donald Trump in June in Singapore.  "We will listen to the North's stance on the inter-Korean summit for this fall, which is agreed upon in the Panmunjom declaration, and share our views," Cho told reporters before heading to the border, referring to the agreement at the April summit. 
 North Korea, which proposed Monday's talks last week, also sent officials overseeing past inter-Korean economic collaborations.  The meeting between Seoul and Pyongyang comes as experts see slow progress on efforts to disarm North Korea since the Singapore summit.
https://newsok.com/article/feed/4789939/rival-koreas-start-talks-meant-to-set-up-leaders-summit ...With the meeting coming amid signs of a stalemate in the political situation as North Korea and the US butt heads over the war-ending declaration and nuclear facility/material reporting and inspection issues, and as North Korea urges the South swiftly implement the Panmunjeom Declaration’s terms, observers are watching to see whether Seoul and Pyongyang can drum up some momentum at the talks and create improvements in their relations.  ...“This morning, the North sent a message proposing to hold high-level talks for implementation of the Panmunjeom Declaration at the Panmunjeom Unification House on Aug. 13 to review implementation of the declaration to date and discuss issues related to inter-Korean summit preparations, and we sent a message this afternoon agreeing to this,” the South Korean Ministry of Unification announced on Sept. 9. ************ The ministry explained that it plans to “form a delegation with Unification Minister Cho Myung-gyon as chief delegate.”
“At the talks, we plan to hold in-depth discussions with the North on ideas to expedite implementation of the Panmunjeom Declaration and the things that will be needed to hold a successful inter-Korean summit,” it added. ...But North Korea’s suggestion of “discussions on inter-Korean summit preparations” as an agenda item for the talks suggests some caution is warranted. The joint press release from the June 1 high-level talks included no mention of a summit, and the two sides have never openly discussed the summit issue at any of their minister-level talks since the first inter-Korean summit in 2000. The “summit” the two sides agreed to discuss at the talks appears to refer to President Moon’s “agree[ment] to visit Pyongyang this fall” as mentioned in the Panmunjeom Declaration. Stressing that Seoul would first need to hear what the North has to say at the talks, multiple key Blue House officials cautiously predicted the preparations were likely for the fall meeting rather than “one-point talks” along the lines of those at a May 26 meeting at the Unification House.
Meanwhile, another source suggested, “We shouldn’t focus too much on the Panmunjeom Declaration’s language about ‘Pyongyang’ and ‘fall’ and rule out the possibility of a ‘one-point summit.’” A source familiar with the situation in inter-Korean relations said, “My understanding is that South and North still have not reached any kind of agreement on a summit date or other specifics.” The main practical issue is the need for the partial lifting of North Korea sanctions and other measures from the US and UN to make enough progress in inter-Korean relations to help jar the political situation out of its current signs of deadlock. This explains the cautious stance voiced by a former senior official and expert on inter-Korean relations, who said the talks’ outcome would be “difficult to predict.” Another source sounded a relatively optimistic note, suggesting that Pyongyang “would not have proposed talks in order to criticize the South.”
http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_northkorea/857113.html North Korea reproached the South on Sunday for siding with the United States’ “sanctions scheme” against the regime, saying such “blind obedience” was hampering progress in fulfilling the Panmunjom Declaration signed by the leaders of the two Koreas on April 27.  The critique came a day before relatively high-level officials from both countries were scheduled to meet in the truce village of Panmunjom. Local analysts believed the regime was sending a message in advance.  Uriminzokkiri, a North Korean government-run propaganda website that caters to audiences outside the country, said ongoing South-North cooperation in various fields wasn’t leading to substantial improvement in bilateral relations and fell short at “forming the atmosphere” for it.  This was so, read the article, because Seoul was handling inter-Korean ties within the realm of internationals sanctions controlled by the United States. Pyongyang specifically vented its frustration about modernization work on North Korean railways and roads that South Korea agreed to assist, saying Seoul was only interested in aspects of the project that “don’t require money,” such as joint research. Seoul is refusing to take the initiative any further at this point, saying that the “conditions” haven’t been met yet, read the article. “South Korea’s repetitive mention of ‘conditions’ refers to the point when the United States and the United Nations ease their sanctions against the North, or in other words, when the North gives up its nuclear weapons,” read the Uriminzokkiri article. “They’re stoically lying beneath the persimmon tree, waiting for a ripe persimmon to fall on its own.” The high-level talks are supposed to begin this morning in the North Korean-controlled building called Tongilgak. South Korea’s side will be represented by Unification Minister Cho Myoung-gyon; Vice Unification Minister Chun Hae-sung; Nam Kwan-pyo, second deputy director of the Blue House’s National Security Office; and Ahn Moon-hyun, deputy director-general for the Prime Minister’s Office.   ...The Blue House said Sunday that the meeting, which was requested by the North last Thursday morning, was expected to decide on the time and venue for South Korean President Moon Jae-in’s third summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.  Seoul believes that another leaders’ meeting will help resolve an impasse in ongoing Pyongyang-Washington denuclearization talks. According to the New York Times last Friday, the North is insisting that the U.S. declare a formal end to the 1950-53 Korean War, which ended in armistice, not a peace treaty, before providing a detailed, written disclosure of its atomic weapons stockpile, its nuclear production facilities and its missiles.  Citing unnamed American officials familiar with the talks, the Times reported that the North has not even agreed to provide that list during private exchanges with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.  Washington has insisted that a formal declaration ending the war could only come after North Korea’s denuclearization.

The rival Koreas will meet Monday for high-level talks meant to prepare for a summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in, South Korea said Thursday, the third such meetings between the leaders in recent months.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2018/08/09/seoul-rival-koreas-leaders-summit/944300002/ The inter-Korean meeting on Monday will be held at Tongilgak, a North Korean-controlled building in the border village of Panmunjom. It wasn’t clear who would attend the talks, but such meetings have typically been handled in the past by South Korea’s unification minister and his counterpart in the North. It also wasn’t clear when another summit might happen, but if the April 27 summit agreements are followed through, the leaders will likely meet in Pyongyang in the next couple of months.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/seoul-rival-koreas-to-meet-to-prepare-for-leaders-summit/2018/08/09/2ec898f8-9ba6-11e8-a8d8-9b4c13286d6b_story.html?utm_term=.93eef1589c9f

80 now 30. But should be around 50-60%. Been too optimistic. Rollercoaster...here we go again!  0.75 290 from 194
Not until the US publicly releases the NK deal and NK shows true signs of landmark change
Thinking the SK is about to stall till after our elections.
I think North Korea is suffering from too much poverty to continue with too much misbehaviour.

So far the talks are progressing well and the visit is in the interest of everyone. Sanctions lifted for NK and very popular peace initiative in SK, resulting in very high approval ratings for Moon.
However: NK might not be really ready to denuclearize. If it becomes apparent before 1/1/2019, Moon might cancel the visit to avoid looking like a fool.

I don't have a lot of direct evidence to support reducing my estimation so comparatively low, but this is what I've been thinking lately: 1. Momentum (and already precarious trust in concrete/immediate change) was undermined after the snafu in Singapore (65%?) 2. S. Korean president wants to capitalize as much as possible on the current situation and works hard for small-level diplomatic endeavors (sports events, reducing border guard, military comm lines, railroads & roadways, forestry meeting, discussing economic cooperation between Russia/SKorea/NKorea, encouraging the US and ASEAN countries to continue to negotiate with N. Korea, etc) in the hopes of maintaining the momentum that is left (95% chance if it was just up to Moon) 3. US continues to keep talks with N. Korea private with little major agreements while negotiating smaller issues like release of soldiers' remains.  In fact, it seems likely that unless Trump's diplomatic & security/military officials can get concrete and clearly positive out of N. Korea, they aren't likely to bring up N. Korea since it makes Trump's "deal" look weak and ineffective, and does so in an unusually tense mid-term Congressional/Senate election year.  And given the face Trump has already lost, they probably want to report more movement from N. Korea than concessions from themselves...and to hold a stiffer line than they might have needed to if Trump hadn't said he'd be tough on a deal, conceded to an empty deal with little middle ground, and then been criticized for doing little or nothing and calling it great.  He now needs a bigger and/or more immediate win on denuclearization or similar concessions than a more moderated approach may have allowed.  So instead we see things like US officials sending out warnings over how N, Korea might try to negotiate commercial networks with neighbors so that goods produced in N. Korea can be sold as made in other countries.  All in all, this looks less than promising. 4. N. Korea continues to threaten pulling back from talking / completing agreements (like family reunions with S. Korea) / criticizing status quo (US should try harder & be less demanding/impatient, criticizing Japan, etc) while maintaining diplomatic talks with S. Korea and also working to keep negotiations going, sending representatives to China (again) to discuss reducing sanctions, etc. while giving up as little as possible (some new work on denuclearization again, perhaps not as superficial as last time and with the hope of showing a "first step" toward a "phased" denuclearization, public urging US to officially end Korean war, etc.) So they would probably welcome Moon, but probably can't offer him more than a handshake an some strong popularity back in S. Korea right now in exchange for a diplomatic visit.  Even Kim gets more than that out of a visit to China, and he's the much weaker party in that exchange.  S. Korea is the stronger party in this exchange and the only very enthusiastic and optimistic neighbor in all the discussions.  And while Moon might be generous enough to extend friendly relations as a neighbor, to return home with less than Trump got (which was remarkably little) would be deeply damaging to Moon in the long run, and he doesn't seem like a stupid or naive politician at all. So...maybe 10-15% chance given N. Korea's stubborn / proud resistance to giving up the little they have for diplomacy and economic relief. 5. China continues to be silent and strategic about allowing N. Korean officials to visit but doing little to exert power in the situation one way or the other, and that silence is even more pronounced in southeast Asia.  And although India with its growing market has shown interest in opening trade with N. Korea, they've been careful in what and how much they're doing, while also seeming to wait to see how things go.  As evidence of what can or should be done to encourage N. Korea or cozy up to them to get them to be more neighborly, 20-30% (more than it's been in a while) 6. Into this silence, Moon Jae-in has been pretty much the only person enthusiastically calling for continued or expanded diplomatic activities to test the resolve of N. Korea and build relationships that encourage trust and partnership in change even if it wasn't strong or genuine to begin with.  In fact, the more Moon Jae-in sends out press releases and speeches about N. Korea and how the US and other ASEAN countries should be taking advantage of the situation with warnings that the opportunity might be lost if others don't participate, the more I feel that he's working to strengthen a weak momentum that is losing ground, despite the show of ongoing diplomacy that peppers headlines on a weekly basis.  See for example https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/south-korean-president-moon-jae-in-seeks-aseans-support-of-korean-peninsula-peace (40% directly against the 95% Moon would offer if it was only up to him) Overall, I wonder how much longer Moon Jae-in can hold out.  He agreed to a visit to Pyongyang in the Panmunjeom Declaration and clearly means to make good on his promise if he can.  But visiting Pyongyang for show and coming back with little more than some photographs doesn't really seem like Moon's style or politically beneficial.  He has enormously high support over N. Korea reconciliation at the moment. But an unreasonably high number of S. Koreans expect denuclearization that may come far more slowly and with less benefit than hoped or not come at all (as it hasn't in the past).  Which is why I imagine Moon is working on a lot of easy, visible diplomatic activities (as many as he can scrounge up, from the sound of it), than he is on moving forward on a trip to Pyongyang to discuss denuclearization.  Such a trip would be expected to connect to a real diplomatic win in some way for S. Korea, and I'm not sure it can right now.  Moon may also have been urged not to go by American officials until they have negotiated something more solid (or suggesting a multi-national summit to redo what the US wasn't able to do?)  Realistically, there is a lot more working against any positive or productive long-term resolutions in N. Korea, and I feel like the clock is ticking down and the farther from June's meeting that we get, the less likely things are to happen, despite Moon's efforts to keep things going.  And although Moon isn't far into his 5-year term, I think this makes it harder for him to sustain this effort in the face of things falling through and showing little.  If he were out soon, he could stake the last months or year of his term on this and at least be lauded for trying.   But new into his presidency, wanting to create positive momentum after a lot of problems in the last presidency, it makes sense that he would push hard on this once-in-his-lifetime opportunity to see if he can make something out of what has in reality been almost nothing so far.  But a loss will follow him and handicap any further expansive projects he might try, and a clear victory seems unlikely or at least difficult to sustain for any length of time.  He needs something to turn in his favor before the end of the summer or he'll have to start backtracking in the Fall.  I'd give his S. Korean support until the end of year before it turns very critical, and longer if he can gain some minor successes.  I think if he hasn't announced or planned a trip by August and made the trip by early October, it's definitely not going to happen. This is what Moon said in May:
..."[Moon] has clearly taken to heart what he sees as the lessons of that stillborn peace initiative.  One lesson was that advancing inter-Korean relations with generous offers of aid was a nonstarter so long as the United States remained locked in a standoff with the North over its nuclear weapons program.  Another was that any deal with North Korea must be struck and carried out early in the terms of the South Korean and American presidents. This ensures that the agreement does not die with a change of governments and political ideologies in Seoul and Washington, as the 2007 agreement and other past deals did.
     “When we look back, the most important thing is speed,” Mr. Moon told the current North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, during their meeting last week in the Demilitarized Zone, the fortified border separating the two Koreas.
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/03/world/asia/north-korea-moon-trump-kim.html ..."Unlike President Donald Trump's administration, "South Koreans aren’t wasting time defining denuclearization," Jean Lee, Korea program director at research group The Wilson Center, wrote in a note this week. "They are pushing ahead with plans for reconciliation with North Korea — with or without the United States."
     Moon has long sought to strengthen bilateral ties through economic development, tourism, and cultural exchange — known as the Sunshine Policy — that will define his legacy. And while his approach has been previously criticized for being too conciliatory, he appears to have robust public support.
     According to a poll from the Asan Institute, a Seoul-based think tank, South Koreans' opinion of North Korea stood at a record high last month. Kim’s favorability rating also hit an all-time high, exceeding both Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Chinese President Xi Jinping.  
     "Many experts criticized the U.S.-North Korea summit for its lack of detailed plans" but "South Koreans put more emphasis on the meeting itself," the Asan Institute said in a report detailing the survey results: "Many, like President Trump, viewed the summit as a positive first step to the complete denuclearization of North Korea."  The poll showed that 71 percent of South Koreans considered the June 12 summit between Trump and Kim a success, with only 10 percent expecting Pyongyang to continue developing nuclear weapons.
     But maintaining the positive momentum could be a challenge for Moon's team. "If there is no tangible progress in peace talks and if North Korea fails to follow through with its agreement, it is likely that South Koreans’ opinions will quickly change again," the Asan Institute warned.
     Seoul's desire to forge ahead with reconciliation projects could also complicate Washington's negotiations with Pyongyang. As Moon expands his charm offensive, the world's largest economy is looking to press Kim's government on the logistics of denuclearization.  "The more protracted the U.S.-North Korean negotiations, the more potential for a gap between Washington and Seoul on North Korea policy as South Korea makes moves to lift its sanctions to allow for economic partnership," said Lee.
https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/12/south-korea-increases-engagement-with-north-korea.html

A new US intelligence assessment says North Korea has been increasing its production of uranium at at least one secret site since the June 12th summit. It’s not clear what the specific contents of the assessment are, how the conclusions were reached, nor the level of confidence in its conclusions. NBC cites one “senior intelligence analyst” who noted, in indirect quotation, that “the decision by Kim to suspend nuclear and missile tests was unexpected, and the fact that the two sides are talking is a positive step,” while also acknowledging that the North is trying to “deceive” the US.  Meanwhile, Reuters reports that Secretary of State Pompeo has cancelled a July 6th meeting with an Indian diplomat to fly out to Pyongyang. The Department of State was tight-lipped on Pompeo’s plans, so it’s not clear if this meeting is related to the aforementioned intelligence assessment. If it is, then it shows that the US government, while alarmed, still views the situation as salvageable. Trump has staked quite a bit of his reputation on improving relations, so he has an incentive to try to keep the wheels from coming off as long as possible. Kim, for his part, also has a strong incentive not to rock the boat too much in order to extract maximum concessions.  All of this has no direct impact on the prospects of an autumnal Kim-Moon summit, but it does hint that the long-anticipated next belligerence phase in the up-and-down cyclicality that characterizes US-NK relations may be coming up soon. On the one hand, a deterioration in relations with the US makes it less likely that Moon will make it out to Pyongyang in September, but at the same time, it could also imply the possibility that Moon will head to Pyongyang sooner than September to try to salvage the current peace phase that has become the cornerstone of his incumbency, as he did when Trump cancelled the summit door the first time.   https://www.nbcnews.com/news/amp/ncna887926 https://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKBN1JO1WP

During the Panmunjeom Summit, Moon made several references to his desire to visit Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang, at one point saying he would visit Pyongyang in the fall, according to South Korean TV news station YTN. Korean media speculates it will be in September, although it may occur sooner. According to the South Korean daily Hankook Ilbo, citing reporting from another South Korean daily Joongang Ilbo (and it should be noted that no other sources are independently verifying the story as of yet), in the letter Kim Jong Un sent to Trump via Kim Yong Chul's White House visit earlier this month, the North Korean leader invited Trump to a follow up summit in Pyongyang in July. Although several South Korean sources have run with this story, I have yet to see any Western or English-language media reporting this. Nevertheless, if true, it is significant because the same source added that "The chances are great that after talks in Singapore, a summit to declarare an end to the [Korean] war involving the US, South Korea, and North Korea will take place in July in Pyongyang." Moon, for various reasons, is reported to be very eager to hold a three-way summit. The Washington Post reported on this back on May 31. The post explains, using reported speech from an anonymous source, that "the Trump administration is currently divided on whether agreeing to a peace treaty at the outset of the talks would give away a significant concession too early in the negotiations." It remains to be seen if this division is still in play, but at least some of Trump's advisors are open to the idea.  Given that both North Korea and the US proclaimed success in Singapore, and given Moon's enthusiasm to meet Kim again, a visit to Pyongyang before the end of the year seems quite likely, irrespective of how relations between Pyongyang and Washington play out.  http://www.ytn.co.kr/_ln/0101_201806111431149478 http://m.hankooki.com/m_dh_view.php?WM=dh&FILE_NO=ZGgyMDE4MDYxMTE1MDMzNDEzNzU5MC5odG0=&ref= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/south-korea-may-try-for-a-three-way-summit-in-singapore-with-us-and-north-korea/2018/05/31/2b1b5d2e-64cb-11e8-b166-fea8410bcded_story.html?utm_term=.7609a3e26974
